previous.name: With Bhāradvāja of the Matted Hair

segments.en: Linked Discourses 7
1. The Perfected Ones
7. With Bhāradvāja the Pure
At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Atha kho suddhikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
segments.en: Then the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Pure went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho suddhikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: and recited this verse in his presence:
“No brahmin in the world is ever purified
even though he’s ethical and mortifies himself.
But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct

segments.pli: So sujjhati na aññā itarā pajā”ti.
segments.en: is purified, not these commoners.”
“Even one who mutters many invocations
is no brahmin by birth
if they’re filthy and corrupt within,
supporting themselves by fraud.
Regardless of whether you’re an aristocrat,
a brahmin, merchant, worker, or an outcaste or scavenger—
if you’re energetic and resolute,
always staunchly vigorous,
you’ll attain the highest happiness.
Know that for a fact, brahmin.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, suddhikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Pure said to the Buddha,
“Excellent, Master Gotama …” …

segments.pli: aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
segments.en: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

suttaplex.blurb: The brahmin Suddhika makes the strikingly Buddhist assertion that mere austerities don’t lead to purity; only knowledge and conduct do.
